child.pub-comments: "Comparative work has been done on Chibchan: Costenla's (1981) dissertation reconstructs the phonology of Proto-Chibchan, using six languages as the basis for the reconstruction - Watuso, Kabekar, Bribri, Teribe, Boruka, and Chibcha - and accounting for the historical phonology of thirteen others. Holt's (1986) dissertation reconstructs the phonology of proto-Chibchan, using six languages as the basis for the reconstruction: Paya, Rama, Bribri, Kuna, Kagaba, Chibcha." (64)

child.publications: Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 64-65. London, New York: Routledge.
Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 64-65. London, New York: Routledge.
Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 64-65. London, New York: Routledge.
child.pub-comments: "'Muisca' is a rendering of the native term muyska 'person'. 'Chibcha' is a native term for the ethnic group and language. It is the first name cited by Lugo, and is established in general usage. The preference by some scholars for 'Muisca' seems designed to leave the term 'Chibcha' as the denomination of the stock, but not of any language in it. Chibcha was the language of a large and important ethnic group at time of contact, and was moderately well documented during the seventeenth century." (64)

child.pub-comments: "Tairona, no longer an ethnic language, is said to be in use as the shamanic/priestly language of the Kogi." (64)

child.pub-comments: "Arwako has always been used by comparative linguists to refer to the whole group to which Ika belongs." (64)

child.pub-comments: "The extinct Wetar was closely related to Watuso, and may have been a dialect of it. Suerre (on the Tortuguero River) cannot be deifinitely identified linguistically, but if anything it is Kabekar or Bribri." (64)

child.publications: Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 64-65. London, New York: Routledge.
Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 64-65. London, New York: Routledge.
child.pub-comments: The author presents Chibchan as a stock, due to the progression of the reconstruction of Proto-Chibchan. Though other authors have proposed macro-phyla of Chibchan, this author limites his to simply Chibchan and the Misumalpan family.

root.publications: Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 64-65. London, New York: Routledge.
root.pub-comments: Though the similarities are not numerous, it is generally recognized that Chibchan and Misumalpan are genetically related.
